newsitem.title: USA: US wilderness groups pleased by west timber deal.
newsitem.headline: US wilderness groups pleased by west timber deal.

text.p: Wilderness advocates said Wednesday they were pleased the timber industry, after a prolonged fight, agreed that sales of old-growth timber off federal lands made to replace ancient Pacific Northwest tree sales comply with environmental laws.

"I think we know now it (replacement timber) won't come from the areas that are off limits now to logging, and there will be environmental laws and public participation," said Patty Goldman of the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund.

But environmentalists said the deal did not answer how the government, with dwindling amounts of old-growth forests on federal land, will be able to find "in-kind" timber to substitute for the ancient Pacific Northwest trees in which the endangered marbled murrelet nests.
The agreement affects timber sales long-stalled because they would damage habitat of the endangered bird.
The timber industry had sued the federal government in August 1995 seeking to exempt the replacement sales from the environmental standards and laws.

"All that happened is that administration has an agreement from the industry that the replacement volume would be sold according to laws, and I think they would have a hard time finding the replacement timber," said Jim Jontz, of the Western Ancient Forest Campaign.
The salvage logging rider, passed last year as part of a broad spending bill, would have forced the government to allow the ancient trees to be logged, but courts then blocked the sales again.
However the federal government was obligated to find replacement timber for those lost sales.
